Using Azure, You have an Azure web service named Contoso2022 that runs in the Standard App Service plan. Contoso2022 has five deployment slots in use.

A user named User1 has the Contributor role for Contoso2022.

You need to ensure that User1 can create additional deployment slots to Contoso2022.

What should you do?

Select only one answer.

1. Assign User1 the Owner role for Contoso2022.

2. Assign User1 the Website Contributor role for Contoso2022.

3. Scale up the Contoso2022 App Service plan.

4. Scale out the Contoso2022 App Service plan.

To allow User1 to create additional deployment slots for Contoso2022, you should assign User1 the Website Contributor role for Contoso2022:

2. Assign User1 the Website Contributor role for Contoso2022.

The Website Contributor role has the ability to create additional deployment slots for the website, so this is the appropriate role to assign to User1 in this scenario.

Here's how you can assign the Website Contributor role to User1:

1. Go to the Azure portal and navigate to the Contoso2022 web service.
2. Click on the "Administration" section in the left-hand menu.
3. Click on the "Security" tab.
4. Click on the "Add role assignments" button.
5. In the "Roles" section, select "Website Contributor".
6. In the "Assign role to" section, type in "User1" (or the name of the user you want to assign the role to) and click "Add role assignment".
7. Click "OK" to save the changes.

After you have assigned the Website Contributor role to User1, they will be able to create additional deployment slots for Contoso2022.

The Continuous Deployment option is a setting in the Azure App Service that determines how new deployments are handled. If the Continuous Deployment option is set to "Disable", it means that new deployments will not be automatically deployed to the production environment, and manual approval is required before the changes can be deployed.

If you are seeing an error that says "Continuous deployment: Disable" and you want to enable continuous deployment, you can do so in the Azure portal by following these steps:

1. Go to the Azure portal and navigate to your App Service plan.
2. Click on the "Settings" button next to the "Deployment" section.
3. Under the "Continuous deployment" section, change the dropdown menu from "Disable" to "Enable".
4. Click "OK" to save the changes.

You have an Azure subscription that includes a virtual network named VNet1.

You plan to create a web app named WebApp1 and deploy it to VNet1.

You need to prepare the environment for the planned web app. The solution must minimize costs.

Which app service plan size should you use?

Select only one answer.

1. Dev / Test F1

2. Dev / Test B1

3. Production P1V2

4. Production P3V3

5. Isolated I1V2

If you want to minimize costs, you should use the "Dev/Test B1" app service plan size for the planned web app, WebApp1.

The "Dev/Test B1" app service plan size is an affordable option that provides a balanced set of compute and memory resources for testing and development scenarios. This plan size is suitable for web apps that do not require a high level of performance or scalability, and is a cost-effective solution for small to medium-sized web apps.

Here's a summary of the other options:

1. "Dev/Test F1" app service plan size: This plan size is intended for small, lightly-trafficked web apps and provides a small amount of compute and memory resources. This plan size is not suitable for web apps that require a high level of performance or scalability.
2. "Production P1V2" app service plan size: This plan size is intended for production web apps that require a high level of performance and scalability. This plan size provides a large amount of compute and memory resources, but is also the most expensive option.
3. "Production P3V3" app service plan size: This plan size provides more compute and memory resources than the "Production P1V2" plan size, but is still intended for production web apps that require a high level of performance and scalability.
4. "Isolated I1V2" app service plan size: This plan size provides a balanced set of compute and memory resources for testing and development scenarios, but with the added benefit of isolated scaling resources. This plan size is suitable for web apps that require a high level of isolation between instances, but may be more expensive than the "Dev/Test B1" plan size.

In summary, if you want to minimize costs and still have enough resources to run your web app, you should use the "Dev/Test B1" app service plan size for WebApp1.
